snippet: The militant Haqqani network’s war against the Soviets more than two decades ago is still spoken of in reverential tones in the mountains of eastern Afghanistan, but support has turned to resentment in some corners.
abstract: Support for the militant Haqqani network in its home turf of Khost, Afghanistan, has turned to resentment in some corners, with leaders of Jalaluddin Haqqani's native Zadran tribe saying they have formally broken with the network; changing attitudes among some in Afghanistan show how much the years of war have changed the social landscape, and how deep the distrust of foreign influence runs among the people.

byline.contributor: Sangar Rahimi and Farooq Jan Mangal contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The militant Haqqani network’s war against the Soviets more than two decades ago is still spoken of in reverential tones in the mountains of eastern Afghanistan, but support has turned to resentment in some corners.

headline.main: Afghan Militant Group Faces Unusual Discontent
headline.print_headline: Afghan Militant Group Faces Unusual Discontent
